1_1_thankuni.Local/Vernacular Names: Bengali: Thankuni; English: Indian Pennywort, Gotu Kola; Hindi: Brahmi
1_1_thankuni.Leaf Morphology: Orbicular-reniform, 3-5cm across, crenate or sub-entire margins, glabrous, radiating nerves
1_1_thankuni.Native Habitat: Tropical wetlands, marshy areas, tropical forests
1_1_thankuni.Global Distribution: India, Bangladesh, Sri Lanka, Southeast Asia, Africa
1_1_thankuni.Primary Active Compounds: Asiaticoside, madecassoside, asiatic acid, madecassic acid
1_1_thankuni.Nutritional Profile: Vitamin C, iron, potassium, calcium, magnesium, amino acids
1_1_thankuni.Therapeutic Properties: Cognitive enhancement, wound healing, anti-inflammatory, antioxidant, anxiolytic
1_1_thankuni.Traditional Uses: Ayurvedic brain tonic, memory enhancement, skin conditions, fever
1_1_thankuni.Modern Clinical Uses: Treatment of cognitive disorders, varicose veins, cellulite, anxiety management
1_1_thankuni.Standard Dosage: 3-6g dried herb daily, or 500-1500mg extract daily
1_1_thankuni.Internal Preparation Method: Decoction, infusion, powder capsules, standardized extract
1_1_thankuni.External Application Method: Poultice, herbal paste, oil infusion, topical cream
1_1_thankuni.Culinary Uses: Edible leaf in salads, herbal teas, smoothies, traditional curries
1_1_thankuni.Extraction Process: Aqueous extraction, alcoholic extraction (60-70% ethanol), CO2 extraction
1_1_thankuni.Toxicity Levels: Very low toxicity; LD50 >5000 mg/kg in animal models
1_1_thankuni.Pregnancy & Lactation Safety: Avoid high doses in pregnancy; minimal use acceptable in lactation under supervision
1_1_thankuni.Drug-Herb Interactions: May enhance effect of sedatives; possible interaction with anticoagulants

1_2_pathorkuchi.Local/Vernacular Names: Bengali: Pathorkuchi, Brahmi; English: Water Hyssop; Hindi: Brahmi, Jal-Brahmi
1_2_pathorkuchi.Leaf Morphology: Small, obovate to spoon-shaped, 4-6mm long, succulent, opposite arrangement
1_2_pathorkuchi.Native Habitat: Tropical wetlands, marshes, pond margins, tropical monsoon forests
1_2_pathorkuchi.Preferred Soil Type: Sandy loam, well-drained moist soil, adaptable to aquatic conditions
1_2_pathorkuchi.Nutritional Profile: Iron, potassium, calcium, magnesium, vitamins A & C
1_2_pathorkuchi.Therapeutic Properties: Nootropic, memory enhancer, adaptogen, anti-anxiety, antioxidant, anti-inflammatory
1_2_pathorkuchi.Traditional Uses: Ayurvedic brain tonic, nerve tonic, cooling, digestive aid, skin conditions
1_2_pathorkuchi.Modern Clinical Uses: Cognitive enhancement, memory disorders, ADHD support, anxiety, depression
1_2_pathorkuchi.Standard Dosage: 4-6g dried herb daily, or 300-600mg extract standardized to 55% bacosides
1_2_pathorkuchi.Internal Preparation Method: Decoction, infusion, aqueous extract, powder, capsules
1_2_pathorkuchi.External Application Method: Oil massage, herbal paste, topical application
1_2_pathorkuchi.Culinary Uses: Herbal teas, smoothies, traditional soups, limited culinary use
1_2_pathorkuchi.Extraction Process: Aqueous extraction, 50-70% ethanol extraction, cold maceration
1_2_pathorkuchi.Contraindications: Pregnancy (high doses avoid), thyroid disorders, GI obstructions
1_2_pathorkuchi.Pregnancy & Lactation Safety: Avoid in first trimester; minimal therapeutic use acceptable later under guidance
1_2_pathorkuchi.Drug-Herb Interactions: May enhance sedatives; caution with CNS depressants, anticoagulants
1_2_pathorkuchi.Conservation Status: Common, IUCN: Not evaluated (widely cultivated, wild populations stable)

1_3_apang.Local/Vernacular Names: Bengali: Apang, Upatlengra, Bilaykhamchi; English: Prickly Chaff Flower; Hindi: Aghada
1_3_apang.Leaf Morphology: Lanceolate to elliptic, 2-5cm long, pubescent, margin entire, opposite arrangement
1_3_apang.Native Habitat: Tropical dry forests, open grasslands, wastelands, disturbed areas
1_3_apang.Global Distribution: India, Bangladesh, tropical Africa, widespread pantropical distribution
1_3_apang.Preferred Soil Type: Sandy loam, well-drained soil, tolerates poor soils
1_3_apang.Therapeutic Properties: Diuretic, laxative, anthelmintic, anti-inflammatory, respiratory support
1_3_apang.Traditional Uses: Ayurvedic treatment for jaundice, urinary troubles, respiratory issues
1_3_apang.Modern Clinical Uses: Urinary tract support, anthelmintic therapy, digestive aid, respiratory health
1_3_apang.Standard Dosage: 3-6g dried herb daily, 1-2 tbsp leaf juice, or decoction
1_3_apang.Culinary Uses: Minimal culinary use; traditionally added to medicinal soups
1_3_apang.Extraction Process: Aqueous decoction, 50% ethanol extraction, juice extraction
1_3_apang.Toxicity Levels: Low; saponin content can cause GI irritation at very high doses
1_3_apang.Contraindications: Pregnancy (uterine stimulant), kidney disease, bleeding disorders
1_3_apang.Pregnancy & Lactation Safety: Avoid in pregnancy; safe in lactation at normal medicinal doses
1_3_apang.Drug-Herb Interactions: May interact with diuretics; caution with blood thinners
1_3_apang.Conservation Status: Common, IUCN: Not evaluated (abundant in native range)

1_4_kalomegh.Local/Vernacular Names: Bengali: Kalomegh, Kalomegh Pata; English: Green Chiretta, King of Bitters; Hindi: Kalmegh
1_4_kalomegh.Leaf Morphology: Linear-lanceolate, 1-5cm long, glabrous, margin entire, opposite arrangement, acute apex
1_4_kalomegh.Native Habitat: Tropical dry forests, cultivated fields, open grasslands
1_4_kalomegh.Global Distribution: India, Bangladesh, throughout Southeast Asia, now cultivated globally
1_4_kalomegh.Preferred Soil Type: Well-drained loamy soil, slightly acidic to neutral pH
1_4_kalomegh.Climate Requirements: Tropical-subtropical, 20-30°C, moderate rainfall (750-2250mm), prefers dry season
1_4_kalomegh.Nutritional Profile: Vitamin A, calcium, phosphorus, potassium, iron
1_4_kalomegh.Traditional Uses: Ayurvedic fever treatment, bitter tonic, liver support, digestive aid, wound healing
1_4_kalomegh.Modern Clinical Uses: Cold/flu treatment, viral infections, liver detoxification, immune support
1_4_kalomegh.Standard Dosage: 3-4g dried herb daily, or 300-400mg standardized extract (andrographolide 10%)
1_4_kalomegh.Internal Preparation Method: Decoction, infusion, powder, standardized extract, fresh juice
1_4_kalomegh.Culinary Uses: Extremely bitter; rarely used in culinary; herbal teas only
1_4_kalomegh.Extraction Process: Aqueous decoction, 60-80% ethanol extraction, water extraction preferred
1_4_kalomegh.Contraindications: Pregnancy (potential uterine effects), severe diarrhea, active bleeding
1_4_kalomegh.Pregnancy & Lactation Safety: Avoid in pregnancy; minimal use acceptable in lactation
1_4_kalomegh.Drug-Herb Interactions: May enhance anticoagulants; caution with immune-suppressing drugs
1_4_kalomegh.Conservation Status: Common, IUCN: Not evaluated (widely cultivated, wild populations declining in some areas)

2_5_kaluchitra.Local/Vernacular Names: Bengali: Kaluchitra, Potala; English: Star Gooseberry, Otaheite Gooseberry; Hindi: Ambla
2_5_kaluchitra.Leaf Morphology: Leaflets small, 0.5-1.5cm, elliptic, feathery bipinnate arrangement, bright green
2_5_kaluchitra.Native Habitat: Tropical deciduous forests, cultivated plantations, tropical wetlands
2_5_kaluchitra.Global Distribution: India, Bangladesh, Southeast Asia, now pan-tropical cultivation
2_5_kaluchitra.Preferred Soil Type: Well-drained loamy soil, slightly acidic, fertile soil
2_5_kaluchitra.Climate Requirements: Tropical, 20-32°C, moderate to high rainfall (1200-2400mm), humid conditions
2_5_kaluchitra.Primary Active Compounds: Vitamin C (ascorbic acid), phyllanthin, hypophyllanthin, phyltetralin
2_5_kaluchitra.Secondary Metabolites: Flavonoids, tannins, alkaloids, polyphenols, ellagic acid
2_5_kaluchitra.Nutritional Profile: Very high vitamin C (600-700mg/100g), copper, zinc, iron, magnesium, vitamin A
2_5_kaluchitra.Traditional Uses: Ayurvedic cooling tonic, liver support, digestive aid, fever management, skin health
2_5_kaluchitra.Modern Clinical Uses: Liver function support, immune enhancement, antioxidant therapy, skin conditions
2_5_kaluchitra.Standard Dosage: Fresh fruit 50-100g daily, or dried fruit powder 3-6g daily
2_5_kaluchitra.Internal Preparation Method: Fresh fruit consumption, decoction of fruit, powder, juice
2_5_kaluchitra.External Application Method: Paste, fruit poultice, leaf decoction wash
2_5_kaluchitra.Culinary Uses: Edible sour fruit in curries, chutneys, pickles, traditional soups
2_5_kaluchitra.Extraction Process: Water extraction, 50% ethanol extraction, cold juice extraction
2_5_kaluchitra.Pregnancy & Lactation Safety: Safe in pregnancy and lactation; traditionally used as nutritive tonic
2_5_kaluchitra.Drug-Herb Interactions: May enhance anticoagulants; minimal interactions expected
2_5_kaluchitra.Conservation Status: Common, IUCN: Not evaluated (widely cultivated, secure)

2_6_ayapan.Local/Vernacular Names: Bengali: Ayapan, Jayanti; English: Sessile Joyweed; Hindi: Jal Brahmi, Punarnava variant
2_6_ayapan.Leaf Morphology: Narrowly elliptic, 1-3cm long, glabrous, opposite arrangement, sessile
2_6_ayapan.Native Habitat: Tropical wetlands, pond margins, marshes, disturbed areas
2_6_ayapan.Global Distribution: India, Bangladesh, pantropical distribution, widespread as weed
2_6_ayapan.Preferred Soil Type: Moist loamy soil, adaptable to wet conditions
2_6_ayapan.Therapeutic Properties: Diuretic, anthelmintic, anti-inflammatory, cooling, digestive support
2_6_ayapan.Traditional Uses: Ayurvedic cooling herb, urinary support, fever reduction, liver support
2_6_ayapan.Modern Clinical Uses: Urinary tract health, digestive support, traditional wetland remedy
2_6_ayapan.Culinary Uses: Edible leaf in soups, curries, traditional water-based dishes
2_6_ayapan.Extraction Process: Aqueous extraction, fresh juice extraction, 50% ethanol extraction
2_6_ayapan.Pregnancy & Lactation Safety: Avoid in pregnancy; minimal use in lactation
2_6_ayapan.Drug-Herb Interactions: May enhance diuretics; caution with potassium-affecting drugs
2_6_ayapan.Conservation Status: Common, IUCN: Not evaluated (abundant, weedy distribution)

2_7_akondo.Local/Vernacular Names: Bengali: Akondo, Akanda; English: Giant Milkweed, Rubber Plant; Hindi: Aak, Madar
2_7_akondo.Leaf Morphology: Oblong-lanceolate, 6-12cm long, pubescent, waxy coating, opposite arrangement
2_7_akondo.Geographical Origin: Tropical Africa, Arabian Peninsula, Indian Subcontinent
2_7_akondo.Native Habitat: Semi-arid regions, dry grasslands, waste areas, xerophytic habitats
2_7_akondo.Global Distribution: Africa, Middle East, India, Bangladesh, pan-tropical
2_7_akondo.Preferred Soil Type: Well-drained sandy soil, poor soil tolerance
2_7_akondo.Nutritional Profile: Limited nutritional value; medicinal compounds predominant
2_7_akondo.Therapeutic Properties: Anti-inflammatory, analgesic, antimicrobial, laxative (caution), skin treatment
2_7_akondo.Traditional Uses: Unani pain relief, traditional skin ulcer treatment, Ayurvedic wound care
2_7_akondo.Modern Clinical Uses: Topical inflammation treatment, traditional dermatological uses
2_7_akondo.Standard Dosage: External use only recommended; internal use highly restricted (0.5-1g leaf powder max)
2_7_akondo.Internal Preparation Method: Minimal internal use; topical paste/oil preferred, restricted decoction
2_7_akondo.External Application Method: Latex paste, herbal oil, leaf poultice, topical application
2_7_akondo.Extraction Process: Oil extraction, alcoholic extraction (external use only)
2_7_akondo.Toxicity Levels: HIGH - Cardiac glycosides; LD50 variable; external use safer than internal
2_7_akondo.Contraindications: Pregnancy AVOID, lactation AVOID, cardiac disease, internal use generally contraindicated
2_7_akondo.Pregnancy & Lactation Safety: ABSOLUTELY CONTRAINDICATED in pregnancy; cardiotoxic potential
2_7_akondo.Drug-Herb Interactions: SERIOUS: Interaction with cardiac drugs, anticoagulants - AVOID if on heart medications
2_7_akondo.Conservation Status: Common, IUCN: Not evaluated (widespread, hardy species)

2_8_bamonhati.Local/Vernacular Names: Bengali: Bamonhati, Shamik; English: Three-flowered Tickclover; Hindi: Shamik
2_8_bamonhati.Leaf Morphology: Trifoliate, leaflets 1-2cm, obovate, glabrous, opposite arrangement
2_8_bamonhati.Native Habitat: Tropical grasslands, forest edges, disturbed areas, cultivated fields
2_8_bamonhati.Global Distribution: India, Bangladesh, Southeast Asia, pantropical distribution
2_8_bamonhati.Traditional Uses: Ayurvedic respiratory tonic, cough relief, asthma support, fever management
2_8_bamonhati.Modern Clinical Uses: Respiratory health support, traditional asthma therapy
2_8_bamonhati.Standard Dosage: 3-6g dried herb daily, decoction or powder
2_8_bamonhati.Culinary Uses: Minimal culinary use; occasional addition to medicinal herbal preparations
2_8_bamonhati.Pregnancy & Lactation Safety: Generally safe in both pregnancy and lactation
2_8_bamonhati.Conservation Status: Common, IUCN: Not evaluated (abundant, widely distributed)

3_9_kalodhutra.Local/Vernacular Names: Bengali: Kalodhutra, Kanto Nota; English: Spiny Amaranth; Hindi: Kanta Nota
3_9_kalodhutra.Leaf Morphology: Broadly lanceolate, 3-7cm, glabrous, alternate arrangement, spines at leaf axils
3_9_kalodhutra.Native Habitat: Open grasslands, disturbed areas, cultivated fields, waste areas
3_9_kalodhutra.Global Distribution: Pantropical, invasive in many regions, common in Bangladesh and India
3_9_kalodhutra.Preferred Soil Type: Well-drained soil, adaptable to poor soils
3_9_kalodhutra.Nutritional Profile: High protein, calcium, iron, phosphorus, vitamin A, beta-carotene
3_9_kalodhutra.Traditional Uses: Ayurvedic cooling tonic, digestive aid, urinary support, fever management
3_9_kalodhutra.Modern Clinical Uses: Nutritional support, traditional digestive and parasitic management
3_9_kalodhutra.Internal Preparation Method: Decoction, fresh juice, powder, cooked as vegetable
3_9_kalodhutra.Culinary Uses: Edible vegetable in curries, soups, stir-fries (young leaves tender)
3_9_kalodhutra.Extraction Process: Aqueous extraction, fresh juice extraction, 50% ethanol
3_9_kalodhutra.Pregnancy & Lactation Safety: Safe; nutritive during pregnancy and lactation
3_9_kalodhutra.Conservation Status: Common, IUCN: Not evaluated (invasive in many regions)

3_10_tarulata.Local/Vernacular Names: Bengali: Tarulata; English: Sweet Broom; Hindi: Jalabruhi, Kaariyanchi
3_10_tarulata.Leaf Morphology: Small, linear-lanceolate, 0.5-2cm, glabrous, whorled arrangement, margin entire
3_10_tarulata.Native Habitat: Tropical grasslands, disturbed areas, cultivated fields, roadside
3_10_tarulata.Global Distribution: Pan-tropical, invasive in many regions, common in Bangladesh
3_10_tarulata.Traditional Uses: Traditional fever remedy, urinary support, skin conditions, digestive aid
3_10_tarulata.Extraction Process: Aqueous decoction, fresh juice extraction, 50% ethanol
3_10_tarulata.Conservation Status: Common, IUCN: Not evaluated (invasive in many regions)

4_11_punarnava.Local/Vernacular Names: Bengali: Punarnava, Kshiringi; English: Spreading Hogweed; Hindi: Punarnava
4_11_punarnava.Leaf Morphology: Ovate, 1-3cm, glabrous to pubescent, slightly fleshy, opposite arrangement
4_11_punarnava.Native Habitat: Open grasslands, disturbed areas, field margins, cultivated fields
4_11_punarnava.Global Distribution: Pantropical, widely distributed in tropical regions
4_11_punarnava.Preferred Soil Type: Well-drained sandy loam, adaptable to poor soils
4_11_punarnava.Traditional Uses: Ayurvedic diuretic and rejuvenative, kidney/urinary support, liver tonic, skin health
4_11_punarnava.Modern Clinical Uses: Kidney function support, diuretic therapy, liver health promotion
4_11_punarnava.Standard Dosage: 3-6g dried herb daily, 1-2 tbsp fresh juice, decoction
4_11_punarnava.Culinary Uses: Minimal culinary use; medicinal herb primarily
4_11_punarnava.Extraction Process: Aqueous decoction, 50% ethanol extraction, juice extraction
4_11_punarnava.Toxicity Levels: Low; rotenone content means moderation advised
4_11_punarnava.Contraindications: Pregnancy, acute kidney disease, diuretic overdose risk
4_11_punarnava.Pregnancy & Lactation Safety: Avoid in pregnancy; minimal use in lactation
4_11_punarnava.Drug-Herb Interactions: May enhance diuretics; caution with potassium-affecting drugs
4_11_punarnava.Conservation Status: Common, IUCN: Not evaluated (abundant and widespread)

4_12_agnishikha.Local/Vernacular Names: Bengali: Agnishikha, Bashok Pata; English: Malabar Nut, Vassa; Hindi: Adusa, Vasa
4_12_agnishikha.Leaf Morphology: Lanceolate, 8-15cm long, acuminate apex, pubescent, opposite arrangement
4_12_agnishikha.Native Habitat: Tropical deciduous forests, forest edges, cultivated areas
4_12_agnishikha.Global Distribution: India, Bangladesh, Southeast Asia, now cultivated widely
4_12_agnishikha.Preferred Soil Type: Well-drained loamy soil, fertile, slightly acidic
4_12_agnishikha.Traditional Uses: Ayurvedic respiratory tonic, cough remedy, asthma support, tuberculosis support
4_12_agnishikha.Modern Clinical Uses: Respiratory health, cough suppression, bronchitis treatment, asthma support
4_12_agnishikha.Standard Dosage: 2-4g dried leaves daily, leaf juice 5-10ml, or standardized extract
4_12_agnishikha.Internal Preparation Method: Decoction, fresh juice, powder, herbal syrup, standardized extract
4_12_agnishikha.Extraction Process: Aqueous decoction, 60% ethanol extraction, juice extraction
4_12_agnishikha.Toxicity Levels: Low; vasicine safe at therapeutic doses
4_12_agnishikha.Contraindications: Pregnancy (mild uterine stimulation), hypotension, cardiac issues
4_12_agnishikha.Pregnancy & Lactation Safety: Avoid in pregnancy; safe in lactation
4_12_agnishikha.Drug-Herb Interactions: May enhance blood pressure-affecting drugs; caution with cardiac meds

4_13_tulsi.Local/Vernacular Names: Bengali: Tulsi, Tulshi; English: Holy Basil; Hindi: Tulsi, Basil, Sharada
4_13_tulsi.Leaf Morphology: Ovate to oblong, 1-3cm, pubescent, margin serrate, opposite arrangement, aromatic
4_13_tulsi.Native Habitat: Tropical regions, cultivated gardens, temple areas
4_13_tulsi.Global Distribution: India, Bangladesh, Southeast Asia, now cultivated globally
4_13_tulsi.Preferred Soil Type: Well-drained loamy soil, fertile, good drainage
4_13_tulsi.Primary Active Compounds: Eugenol, orientin, vicenin, rosmarinic acid, apigenin
4_13_tulsi.Nutritional Profile: Vitamin A, C, calcium, iron, potassium, manganese
4_13_tulsi.Traditional Uses: Ayurvedic adaptogen, stress relief, fever management, cough remedy, spiritual herb
4_13_tulsi.Modern Clinical Uses: Stress and anxiety management, immune support, antioxidant therapy, respiratory health
4_13_tulsi.Standard Dosage: 2-4g dried leaves daily, fresh leaf juice 5-10ml, or 300-600mg extract
4_13_tulsi.Internal Preparation Method: Fresh juice, herbal tea, powder, decoction, standardized extract
4_13_tulsi.External Application Method: Leaf paste, topical application, essential oil massage
4_13_tulsi.Culinary Uses: Edible leaves in teas, traditional Indian curries, garnish, spice
4_13_tulsi.Extraction Process: Water extraction, 60-70% ethanol extraction, essential oil distillation, cold infusion
4_13_tulsi.Toxicity Levels: Very low; safe herb with extensive traditional use
4_13_tulsi.Contraindications: Pregnancy (mild stimulation), hypoglycemia risk with some preparation
4_13_tulsi.Pregnancy & Lactation Safety: Generally safe in pregnancy and lactation at normal culinary/mild therapeutic doses
4_13_tulsi.Drug-Herb Interactions: May enhance anticoagulants; minimal interactions otherwise
4_13_tulsi.Conservation Status: Common, IUCN: Not evaluated (widely cultivated, sacred status)

4_14_ramtulshi.Local/Vernacular Names: Bengali: Ramtulshi, Sweet Basil; English: Sweet Basil, Garden Basil; Hindi: Ram Tulsi
4_14_ramtulshi.Leaf Morphology: Ovate to oblong, 2-4cm, glabrous to pubescent, margin entire/serrate, opposite arrangement
4_14_ramtulshi.Native Habitat: Tropical and subtropical regions, cultivated globally
4_14_ramtulshi.Global Distribution: Widely cultivated throughout temperate and tropical regions
4_14_ramtulshi.Preferred Soil Type: Well-drained loamy soil, fertile, good drainage
4_14_ramtulshi.Climate Requirements: Warm temperate to tropical, 18-28°C, moderate rainfall (500-1500mm)
4_14_ramtulshi.Primary Active Compounds: Estragole, linalool, methyl cinnamate, eugenol (less than O. sanctum)
4_14_ramtulshi.Nutritional Profile: Vitamin A, C, K, calcium, iron, manganese, magnesium
4_14_ramtulshi.Therapeutic Properties: Antimicrobial, anti-inflammatory, antioxidant, digestive support, carminative
4_14_ramtulshi.Traditional Uses: Culinary herb with medicinal properties, digestive aid, fever support
4_14_ramtulshi.Modern Clinical Uses: Digestive health, antimicrobial support, culinary and medicinal applications
4_14_ramtulshi.Standard Dosage: 2-4g dried leaves daily, fresh juice 5-10ml, or as culinary spice
4_14_ramtulshi.Internal Preparation Method: Fresh herb, herbal tea, powder, decoction, culinary use
4_14_ramtulshi.External Application Method: Leaf paste, essential oil, topical application
4_14_ramtulshi.Culinary Uses: Extensively used in Italian and Mediterranean cuisine, teas, pesto, garnish
4_14_ramtulshi.Extraction Process: Water extraction, 50% ethanol extraction, essential oil distillation
4_14_ramtulshi.Toxicity Levels: Very low; culinary herb, safe with common use
4_14_ramtulshi.Contraindications: Rare; estragole at very high doses considered (normal use safe)
4_14_ramtulshi.Pregnancy & Lactation Safety: Safe in pregnancy and lactation at normal culinary amounts
4_14_ramtulshi.Conservation Status: Common, IUCN: Not evaluated (widely cultivated globally)

4_15_basok.Local/Vernacular Names: Bengali: Basok, Bashak; English: Malabar Nut, Adatoda; Hindi: Adusa
4_15_basok.Leaf Morphology: Lanceolate, 10-18cm long, acuminate, pubescent, opposite arrangement
4_15_basok.Native Habitat: Tropical deciduous forests, forest margins, cultivated areas
4_15_basok.Preferred Soil Type: Well-drained loamy soil, fertile, slightly acidic
4_15_basok.Traditional Uses: Ayurvedic cough remedy, respiratory support, asthma management, lung health
4_15_basok.Modern Clinical Uses: Respiratory health, bronchitis treatment, cough suppression, asthma support
4_15_basok.Standard Dosage: 2-4g dried leaves daily, leaf juice 5-10ml, or standardized extract
4_15_basok.Internal Preparation Method: Decoction, fresh juice, powder, syrup, standardized extract
4_15_basok.Extraction Process: Aqueous decoction, 60% ethanol extraction, juice extraction
4_15_basok.Toxicity Levels: Low; vasicine safe at therapeutic doses
4_15_basok.Contraindications: Pregnancy (mild uterine effects), hypotension, cardiac disease
4_15_basok.Pregnancy & Lactation Safety: Avoid in pregnancy; safe in lactation
4_15_basok.Drug-Herb Interactions: May enhance blood pressure drugs; caution with cardiac medications

4_16_neem.Local/Vernacular Names: Bengali: Neem, Nim; English: Indian Lilac, Neem Tree; Hindi: Neem, Nimb
4_16_neem.Leaf Morphology: Pinnate, leaflets lanceolate, 2-4cm, glabrous, serrate margin, feathery appearance
4_16_neem.Native Habitat: Tropical dry forests, deciduous forests, semi-arid regions
4_16_neem.Global Distribution: India, Bangladesh, pantropical cultivation, adapted globally
4_16_neem.Preferred Soil Type: Well-drained loamy soil, tolerates poor soils, slightly acidic to alkaline
4_16_neem.Primary Active Compounds: Azadirachtin (limonoid), nimbin, salannin, mahagoni, fatty acids
4_16_neem.Nutritional Profile: Vitamin A, C, iron, calcium, phosphorus, healthy fatty acids (seed oil)
4_16_neem.Therapeutic Properties: Antimicrobial, antifungal, anthelmintic, anti-inflammatory, immunomodulating, skin health
4_16_neem.Traditional Uses: Ayurvedic purifying herb, skin conditions, fever, parasites, liver support
4_16_neem.Modern Clinical Uses: Antimicrobial therapy, antifungal support, dental health, immune enhancement
4_16_neem.Standard Dosage: 3-6g dried leaves daily, leaf juice 5-10ml, neem oil applied topically only
4_16_neem.Internal Preparation Method: Decoction, powder, fresh juice, limited internal use of leaf extract
4_16_neem.External Application Method: Neem oil topical application, paste, poultice, skin wash
4_16_neem.Culinary Uses: Neem leaves occasionally in curry (bitter), not common culinary use
4_16_neem.Extraction Process: Oil pressing (seed), aqueous decoction (leaf), 50% ethanol extraction
4_16_neem.Toxicity Levels: Low for leaves; neem oil seed extract has moderate toxicity (LD50 31.62 mg/kg extract)
4_16_neem.Contraindications: Pregnancy AVOID internal use (potential teratogenic effects with seed oil), lactation caution
4_16_neem.Pregnancy & Lactation Safety: AVOID seed oil in pregnancy (teratogenic potential); leaf use minimal and cautious
4_16_neem.Drug-Herb Interactions: May enhance anticoagulants; caution with immune-suppressing drugs, blood thinners
4_16_neem.Conservation Status: Common, IUCN: Not evaluated (widespread, sacred and protected)

4_17_pudina.Local/Vernacular Names: Bengali: Pudina, Peppermint; English: Peppermint; Hindi: Pudina
4_17_pudina.Leaf Morphology: Lanceolate to elliptic, 2-4cm, glabrous, serrate margin, opposite arrangement, aromatic
4_17_pudina.Native Habitat: Temperate to subtropical regions, cultivated globally
4_17_pudina.Global Distribution: Cultivated worldwide in temperate and subtropical regions
4_17_pudina.Climate Requirements: Temperate to subtropical, 10-28°C, moderate rainfall (500-1500mm), frost hardy
4_17_pudina.Secondary Metabolites: Flavonoids, tannins, phenolic compounds, rosmarinic acid
4_17_pudina.Nutritional Profile: Vitamin A, C, minerals, manganese, iron
4_17_pudina.Therapeutic Properties: Antispasmodic, carminative, digestive aid, cooling, antimicrobial, anti-inflammatory
4_17_pudina.Traditional Uses: Ayurvedic cooling herb, digestive aid, headache relief, respiratory support
4_17_pudina.Modern Clinical Uses: Digestive health, IBS support, headache and migraine management, cooling remedy
4_17_pudina.Standard Dosage: 2-4g dried leaves daily, fresh juice 5-10ml, or essential oil 1-3 drops
4_17_pudina.Internal Preparation Method: Herbal tea, infusion, fresh juice, powder, essential oil (cautious internal use)
4_17_pudina.External Application Method: Leaf paste, essential oil topical (diluted), massage oil
4_17_pudina.Culinary Uses: Extensively used in teas, beverages, desserts, savory dishes, candy, garnish
4_17_pudina.Extraction Process: Water extraction, 50% ethanol extraction, essential oil steam distillation
4_17_pudina.Toxicity Levels: Very low; safe culinary herb, essential oil caution in high doses
4_17_pudina.Contraindications: Infants/young children (menthol caution), GERD aggravation possible, pregnancy minimal concern
4_17_pudina.Pregnancy & Lactation Safety: Safe in pregnancy and lactation at normal culinary and mild therapeutic doses
4_17_pudina.Drug-Herb Interactions: Minimal interactions; may slightly enhance some medications
4_17_pudina.Conservation Status: Common, IUCN: Not evaluated (widely cultivated, hybrid species)

4_18_joba.Local/Vernacular Names: Bengali: Joba, Loha; English: Roselle, Red Sorrel, Hibiscus; Hindi: Jaba
4_18_joba.Leaf Morphology: Deeply lobed, 3-5 lobes, 5-10cm, serrate, glabrous to pubescent, alternate arrangement
4_18_joba.Native Habitat: Tropical grasslands, cultivated fields, open areas
4_18_joba.Global Distribution: Pantropical cultivation, India, Bangladesh, Africa, Caribbean
4_18_joba.Preferred Soil Type: Well-drained loamy soil, fertile, slightly acidic to neutral
4_18_joba.Primary Active Compounds: Anthocyanins, flavonoids (hibiscetine), organic acids (citric, malic, tartaric)
4_18_joba.Secondary Metabolites: Polyphenols, tannins, protocatechuic acid, hibiscic acid
4_18_joba.Nutritional Profile: Vitamin C, vitamin A, calcium, iron, phosphorus, antioxidants
4_18_joba.Traditional Uses: Ayurvedic cooling tonic, blood pressure support, digestive aid, menstrual support
4_18_joba.Modern Clinical Uses: Blood pressure management, antioxidant therapy, metabolic syndrome support
4_18_joba.Standard Dosage: 2-4g dried calyces daily, herbal tea 1-3 cups daily
4_18_joba.Internal Preparation Method: Herbal tea, decoction, fresh juice, powder
4_18_joba.Culinary Uses: Extensively used in teas, beverages, jams, chutneys, sauces, garnish
4_18_joba.Extraction Process: Water extraction (tea preferred), 50% ethanol extraction, juice extraction
4_18_joba.Contraindications: Pregnancy (mild uterine effects in some studies), kidney disease caution
4_18_joba.Pregnancy & Lactation Safety: Generally safe at normal culinary amounts; avoid high medicinal doses in pregnancy
4_18_joba.Drug-Herb Interactions: May enhance blood pressure drugs; minimal other interactions

4_19_sojina.Local/Vernacular Names: Bengali: Sojina, Sojne; English: Drumstick Tree, Moringa; Hindi: Shigru, Sahjan
4_19_sojina.Leaf Morphology: Tripinnate, leaflets small (0.3-0.8cm), ovate, glabrous, feathery appearance
4_19_sojina.Native Habitat: Tropical dry forests, semi-arid regions, cultivated widely
4_19_sojina.Global Distribution: India, Bangladesh, Africa, now pantropical cultivation
4_19_sojina.Preferred Soil Type: Well-drained sandy loam, tolerates poor soils, slightly alkaline to neutral
4_19_sojina.Primary Active Compounds: Proteins, amino acids, vitamins A/C, minerals, glucosinolates, niazimicin
4_19_sojina.Nutritional Profile: Exceptional nutrition: protein 25-30%, vitamin C, vitamin A, calcium, iron (leaves are superfood)
4_19_sojina.Therapeutic Properties: Antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, antimicrobial, anticancer potential, nutritive
4_19_sojina.Traditional Uses: Ayurvedic nutritive tonic, blood support, energy enhancement, skin health
4_19_sojina.Modern Clinical Uses: Nutritional support, antioxidant therapy, blood health, energy and stamina
4_19_sojina.Standard Dosage: Fresh leaves 50-100g daily, dried powder 3-6g daily, standardized extract
4_19_sojina.Internal Preparation Method: Fresh leaves cooked, powder, herbal tea, decoction, juice extraction
4_19_sojina.Culinary Uses: Edible leaves in curries, pods as vegetable, seeds for oil (culinary and medicinal)
4_19_sojina.Extraction Process: Water extraction, 50-70% ethanol extraction, cold pressing (seed oil)
4_19_sojina.Contraindications: None significant; root traditionally avoided in pregnancy (uterine stimulant potential)
4_19_sojina.Pregnancy & Lactation Safety: Leaves safe in pregnancy and lactation (nutritive); avoid root in pregnancy
4_19_sojina.Conservation Status: Common, IUCN: Not evaluated (widely cultivated, important food crop)

5_20_gandha.Local/Vernacular Names: Bengali: Gandha, Gandha Raj, Jaba; English: Flame of the Forest, Jungle Geranium; Hindi: Ixora
5_20_gandha.Global Distribution: India, Bangladesh, tropical Asia, cultivated ornamentally
5_20_gandha.Preferred Soil Type: Well-drained loamy soil, fertile, slightly acidic
5_20_gandha.Nutritional Profile: Limited nutritional value; medicinal compounds predominant
5_20_gandha.Therapeutic Properties: Anti-inflammatory, antimicrobial, astringent, anthelmintic, skin health
5_20_gandha.Traditional Uses: Traditional skin conditions, wound healing, fever management, parasitic support
5_20_gandha.Modern Clinical Uses: Topical inflammation and skin health support
5_20_gandha.Standard Dosage: 3-6g dried flower/leaf daily, decoction, limited use
5_20_gandha.External Application Method: Paste, poultice, topical application, flower decoction wash
5_20_gandha.Conservation Status: Common, IUCN: Not evaluated (widely cultivated ornamental)

5_21_shotomuli.Local/Vernacular Names: Bengali: Shotomuli; English: Whorled Solomon's Seal; Hindi: Miryakandi
5_21_shotomuli.Leaf Morphology: Lanceolate, 5-8cm, glabrous, whorled arrangement (variable), margin entire
5_21_shotomuli.Native Habitat: Temperate to subtropical forests, shaded areas, mountainous regions
5_21_shotomuli.Preferred Soil Type: Well-drained loamy soil, shade-loving, forest soil
5_21_shotomuli.Therapeutic Properties: Demulcent, anthelmintic, anti-inflammatory, respiratory support, joint health
5_21_shotomuli.Traditional Uses: Traditional respiratory support, joint health, rheumatic conditions
5_21_shotomuli.Conservation Status: Common in native habitat, IUCN: Not evaluated (wild populations fair)

6_22_sarpagandha.Local/Vernacular Names: Bengali: Sarpagandha, Chandrika; English: Indian Snakeroot; Hindi: Sarpagandha
6_22_sarpagandha.Leaf Morphology: Lanceolate, 8-12cm, glabrous, whorled arrangement (3 per node), acuminate
6_22_sarpagandha.Native Habitat: Tropical wet and dry forests, shaded forest areas
6_22_sarpagandha.Global Distribution: India, Bangladesh, endemic to Indian subcontinent
6_22_sarpagandha.Preferred Soil Type: Well-drained loamy soil, fertile, forest soil, slightly acidic
6_22_sarpagandha.Therapeutic Properties: Antihypertensive, sedative, tranquilizing, antiarrhythmic, antipsychotic potential
6_22_sarpagandha.Traditional Uses: Ayurvedic nervous system support, hypertension management, mental conditions
6_22_sarpagandha.Modern Clinical Uses: Blood pressure management (historical), psychiatric conditions, sedative therapy
6_22_sarpagandha.Medicinal Part Used: Root and root bark (primary source of alkaloids)
6_22_sarpagandha.Standard Dosage: 0.5-1g dried root daily, or 50-100mg standardized alkaloid extract
6_22_sarpagandha.Extraction Process: Aqueous decoction, 50% ethanol extraction, pharmaceutical alkaloid isolation
6_22_sarpagandha.Toxicity Levels: Moderate; alkaloid content requires careful dosing (LD50 320 mg/kg in animal models)
6_22_sarpagandha.Contraindications: Pregnancy AVOID (teratogenic potential), depression, lactation AVOID, cardiac arrhythmias with caution
6_22_sarpagandha.Pregnancy & Lactation Safety: CONTRAINDICATED in pregnancy; potentially teratogenic; avoid in lactation
6_22_sarpagandha.Drug-Herb Interactions: SERIOUS: Interactions with blood pressure meds, antidepressants, cardiac drugs - medical supervision needed
6_22_sarpagandha.Conservation Status: Vulnerable, IUCN: Endangered (overharvesting, habitat loss, medicinal demand)

6_23_anantamul.Local/Vernacular Names: Bengali: Anantamul, Ananta Moola; English: Indian Sarsaparilla; Hindi: Anantamul
6_23_anantamul.Leaf Morphology: Lanceolate-elliptic, 2-4cm, glabrous, opposite arrangement, margin entire
6_23_anantamul.Native Habitat: Tropical deciduous forests, open grasslands, cultivation
6_23_anantamul.Preferred Soil Type: Well-drained sandy loam, adaptable, slightly acidic
6_23_anantamul.Therapeutic Properties: Blood purifier, anti-inflammatory, antimicrobial, skin health, cooling
6_23_anantamul.Traditional Uses: Ayurvedic blood purification, skin conditions, rheumatic support, cooling tonic
6_23_anantamul.Modern Clinical Uses: Blood health support, skin condition management, detoxification support
6_23_anantamul.Standard Dosage: 3-6g dried root daily, decoction or powder
6_23_anantamul.Extraction Process: Aqueous decoction, 50% ethanol extraction, juice extraction

6_24_chapalish.Local/Vernacular Names: Bengali: Chapalish, Chapaliza; English: Black Fruit Ylang-Ylang; Hindi: Chapaliza
6_24_chapalish.Leaf Morphology: Elliptic-lanceolate, 8-15cm, glabrous, alternate arrangement, acuminate apex
6_24_chapalish.Preferred Soil Type: Well-drained loamy soil, fertile, slightly acidic
6_24_chapalish.Nutritional Profile: Limited nutritional value; medicinal compounds predominant
6_24_chapalish.Traditional Uses: Traditional digestive aid, fever management, skin conditions
6_24_chapalish.Culinary Uses: Minimal culinary use; fragrant flower ornamental

6_25_amloki.Local/Vernacular Names: Bengali: Amloki, Amlika; English: Indian Gooseberry, Amla; Hindi: Amlika, Amalaki
6_25_amloki.Leaf Morphology: Leaflets small, 0.4-0.8cm, pinnate feathery arrangement, light green
6_25_amloki.Preferred Soil Type: Well-drained loamy soil, slightly acidic to alkaline, fertile
6_25_amloki.Primary Active Compounds: Vitamin C (ascorbic acid), phyllemblic acid, emblicanin A & B, tannins
6_25_amloki.Secondary Metabolites: Flavonoids, polyphenols, gallic acid, ellagic acid
6_25_amloki.Nutritional Profile: Exceptionally high vitamin C (600-700mg/100g), copper, zinc, iron, manganese
6_25_amloki.Traditional Uses: Ayurvedic rejuvenative tonic, immune support, cooling, digestive aid (Triphala ingredient)
6_25_amloki.Modern Clinical Uses: Antioxidant therapy, immune enhancement, liver function support, aging management
6_25_amloki.Standard Dosage: Fresh fruit 50-100g daily, or 3-6g dried fruit powder daily
6_25_amloki.Internal Preparation Method: Fresh fruit, dried powder, decoction, juice, herbal jam (Amla murabba)
6_25_amloki.External Application Method: Paste, topical oil (from seeds), herbal wash
6_25_amloki.Culinary Uses: Edible fruit in fresh form, chutneys, pickles, jams, traditional sweets
6_25_amloki.Extraction Process: Water extraction, 50% ethanol extraction, juice extraction, powder preparation
6_25_amloki.Pregnancy & Lactation Safety: Safe and beneficial in pregnancy and lactation; traditional rejuvenative
6_25_amloki.Drug-Herb Interactions: May enhance anticoagulants; minimal other interactions
6_25_amloki.Conservation Status: Common, IUCN: Not evaluated (widely cultivated, secure)

6_26_haritoki.Local/Vernacular Names: Bengali: Haritoki, Harali; English: Black Myrobalan, Chebulic Myrobalan; Hindi: Harad
6_26_haritoki.Leaf Morphology: Elliptic, 8-15cm, glabrous, opposite to subopposite arrangement, leathery
6_26_haritoki.Native Habitat: Tropical deciduous and dry forests, cultivated
6_26_haritoki.Preferred Soil Type: Well-drained loamy soil, adaptable, tolerates poor soils
6_26_haritoki.Primary Active Compounds: Tannins (30-35%), chebulic acid, ellagic acid, gallic acid, ascorbic acid
6_26_haritoki.Therapeutic Properties: Astringent, laxative (mild), anthelmintic, hepatoprotective, rejuvenative, taste support
6_26_haritoki.Traditional Uses: Ayurvedic rasayana (rejuvenative), digestive aid, parasitic support, taste enhancer (Triphala ingredient)
6_26_haritoki.Modern Clinical Uses: Digestive health, anthelmintic therapy, hepatoprotection, antioxidant support
6_26_haritoki.Standard Dosage: 3-6g dried fruit powder daily, decoction, or as part of Triphala formulation
6_26_haritoki.Culinary Uses: Limited culinary use; primarily medicinal; occasional spice
6_26_haritoki.Extraction Process: Water extraction, 50% ethanol extraction, powder preparation
6_26_haritoki.Toxicity Levels: Very low; safe at therapeutic doses
6_26_haritoki.Pregnancy & Lactation Safety: Safe in pregnancy and lactation at normal medicinal doses; mild laxative action acceptable
6_26_haritoki.Drug-Herb Interactions: May enhance anticoagulants; minimal other interactions
6_26_haritoki.Conservation Status: Common, IUCN: Not evaluated (widely cultivated and wild populations stable)

6_27_bohera.Local/Vernacular Names: Bengali: Bohera, Bohera; English: Bastard Myrobalan, Belleric Myrobalan; Hindi: Bahera
6_27_bohera.Leaf Morphology: Obovate to elliptic, 10-20cm, glabrous, alternate to subopposite, leathery
6_27_bohera.Preferred Soil Type: Well-drained loamy soil, adaptable, tolerates poor soils
6_27_bohera.Primary Active Compounds: Tannins (25-30%), belliric acid, polyphenols, vitamin C
6_27_bohera.Therapeutic Properties: Astringent, cooling, anthelmintic, hepatoprotective, eye health support
6_27_bohera.Traditional Uses: Ayurvedic eye tonic, respiratory support, fever management, cooling (Triphala ingredient)
6_27_bohera.Modern Clinical Uses: Eye health support, respiratory support, anthelmintic therapy
6_27_bohera.Standard Dosage: 3-6g dried fruit powder daily, decoction, or as part of Triphala
6_27_bohera.Extraction Process: Water extraction, 50% ethanol extraction, powder preparation
6_27_bohera.Toxicity Levels: Very low; safe at therapeutic doses
6_27_bohera.Pregnancy & Lactation Safety: Safe in pregnancy and lactation at normal medicinal doses
6_27_bohera.Conservation Status: Common, IUCN: Not evaluated (widely cultivated and wild populations stable)

6_28_oshwagandha.Local/Vernacular Names: Bengali: Oshwagandha, Ashwagandha; English: Indian Ginseng, Winter Cherry; Hindi: Ashwagandha
6_28_oshwagandha.Leaf Morphology: Ovate to lanceolate, 3-8cm, pubescent, alternate arrangement, margin entire
6_28_oshwagandha.Native Habitat: Tropical dry forests, arid regions, cultivated
6_28_oshwagandha.Global Distribution: India, Bangladesh, Middle East, now cultivated globally
6_28_oshwagandha.Preferred Soil Type: Well-drained sandy loam, drought tolerant, slightly alkaline
6_28_oshwagandha.Nutritional Profile: Iron, zinc, mineral content moderate, withanolides predominant
6_28_oshwagandha.Therapeutic Properties: Adaptogenic, anxiolytic, anti-inflammatory, antioxidant, immunomodulating, stress support
6_28_oshwagandha.Traditional Uses: Ayurvedic rasayana (rejuvenative), adaptogen, male fertility support, stress and sleep support
6_28_oshwagandha.Modern Clinical Uses: Stress and anxiety management, athletic performance, cognitive enhancement, male fertility
6_28_oshwagandha.Standard Dosage: 3-6g dried root powder daily, or 300-500mg standardized extract (5-10% withanolides)
6_28_oshwagandha.Internal Preparation Method: Decoction, powder, standardized extract, milk decoction (traditional)
6_28_oshwagandha.Culinary Uses: Minimal; primarily medicinal; occasional traditional use
6_28_oshwagandha.Extraction Process: Aqueous decoction, 50-70% ethanol extraction, standardized extraction
6_28_oshwagandha.Contraindications: Pregnancy (mild uterine effects in some studies - caution), autoimmune conditions (possible immune enhancement)
6_28_oshwagandha.Pregnancy & Lactation Safety: Generally regarded as safe but use with caution in pregnancy; acceptable in lactation
6_28_oshwagandha.Drug-Herb Interactions: May enhance sedatives and anxiolytics; possible interaction with thyroid medications
6_28_oshwagandha.Conservation Status: Common, IUCN: Not evaluated (widely cultivated, wild populations declining in some regions)

6_29_devils_backbone.Local/Vernacular Names: Bengali: Devil's Backbone, Zig-Zag Plant; English: Devil's Backbone, Redbird Cactus; Hindi: Nagadaman
6_29_devils_backbone.Leaf Morphology: Opposite, elliptic-obovate, 2-5cm, glabrous, margin entire, variegated in some varieties
6_29_devils_backbone.Preferred Soil Type: Well-drained sandy loam, drought tolerant, poor soil adaptable
6_29_devils_backbone.Climate Requirements: Tropical-subtropical, 20-30°C, moderate to low rainfall, drought tolerant
6_29_devils_backbone.Nutritional Profile: Limited nutritional value; potential toxic compounds
6_29_devils_backbone.Therapeutic Properties: Limited medicinal use; traditional antimicrobial, anthelmintic (caution required)
6_29_devils_backbone.Traditional Uses: Limited traditional medicinal use; primarily ornamental
6_29_devils_backbone.Modern Clinical Uses: Minimal; caution due to potential toxins
6_29_devils_backbone.Standard Dosage: Minimal; external use preferred, very limited internal use (0.1-0.5g maximum)
6_29_devils_backbone.Internal Preparation Method: Strictly LIMITED use; external only recommended
6_29_devils_backbone.Extraction Process: Water extraction limited; external application preferred
6_29_devils_backbone.Toxicity Levels: MODERATE - Cardiac glycosides present; potential toxicity
6_29_devils_backbone.Contraindications: Pregnancy AVOID, lactation AVOID, cardiac disease, internal use generally contraindicated
6_29_devils_backbone.Pregnancy & Lactation Safety: AVOID in pregnancy and lactation; cardiac glycoside toxicity risk
6_29_devils_backbone.Drug-Herb Interactions: SERIOUS: Potential interactions with cardiac drugs - avoid if on heart medications

7_30_lemongrass.Local/Vernacular Names: Bengali: Lemongrass, Sera Ghash; English: Lemongrass, West Indian Lemongrass; Hindi: Nimboo Ghash
7_30_lemongrass.Leaf Morphology: Long, linear, 30-90cm, narrow (0.3-0.5cm wide), blade margins rough/serrulate, tufted
7_30_lemongrass.Global Distribution: India, Bangladesh, Southeast Asia, now cultivated tropically worldwide
7_30_lemongrass.Preferred Soil Type: Well-drained loamy soil, fertile, slightly acidic to neutral
7_30_lemongrass.Climate Requirements: Tropical-subtropical, 20-30°C, moderate rainfall (750-2000mm), warm growing conditions
7_30_lemongrass.Nutritional Profile: Vitamin A, C, minerals (magnesium, potassium, zinc), antioxidants
7_30_lemongrass.Therapeutic Properties: Antimicrobial, antifungal, insecticidal, anti-inflammatory, digestive support, calming
7_30_lemongrass.Traditional Uses: Traditional digestive aid, fever management, insect repellent, calming tea
7_30_lemongrass.Modern Clinical Uses: Antimicrobial support, digestive health, food preservation, aromatherapy
7_30_lemongrass.Standard Dosage: 3-6g dried leaves daily, fresh juice 5-10ml, or 1-3 cups herbal tea
7_30_lemongrass.Internal Preparation Method: Herbal tea, fresh juice, infusion, dried powder, essential oil (cautious)
7_30_lemongrass.External Application Method: Essential oil massage (diluted), leaf poultice, topical application
7_30_lemongrass.Culinary Uses: Extensively used in Asian cuisine, teas, beverages, curry, soups, stir-fries
7_30_lemongrass.Extraction Process: Water extraction (tea), steam distillation (essential oil), 50% ethanol extraction
7_30_lemongrass.Toxicity Levels: Very low; food-grade herb, essential oil requires caution in high doses
7_30_lemongrass.Contraindications: Pregnancy (minimal concern at culinary amounts), essential oil internal use caution
7_30_lemongrass.Pregnancy & Lactation Safety: Safe in pregnancy and lactation at normal culinary amounts
7_30_lemongrass.Drug-Herb Interactions: Minimal interactions; safe with most medications

7_31_aloe_vera.Local/Vernacular Names: Bengali: Aloe Vera, Ghritkumari; English: Aloe Vera, Medicinal Aloe; Hindi: Ghitkumari
7_31_aloe_vera.Leaf Morphology: Lanceolate, succulent, 30-60cm long, blue-green, margin serrate with teeth, thick gel interior
7_31_aloe_vera.Geographical Origin: North Africa, Arabian Peninsula, naturalized in Mediterranean
7_31_aloe_vera.Native Habitat: Arid and semi-arid regions, xerophytic habitats
7_31_aloe_vera.Global Distribution: Pantropical cultivation, widely cultivated, naturalized globally
7_31_aloe_vera.Preferred Soil Type: Well-drained sandy soil, drought tolerant, poor soil adaptable
7_31_aloe_vera.Climate Requirements: Tropical-subtropical, 15-32°C, drought tolerant, low rainfall (250-1000mm), frost sensitive
7_31_aloe_vera.Primary Active Compounds: Polysaccharides (acemannan), mucilage, anthraquinones (aloin, barbaloin), salicylic acid
7_31_aloe_vera.Secondary Metabolites: Vitamins (A, B, C, E), minerals (Ca, Mg, K, Zn), amino acids (20), enzymes
7_31_aloe_vera.Nutritional Profile: High in water, polysaccharides, vitamins, minerals, amino acids
7_31_aloe_vera.Therapeutic Properties: Skin healing, moisturizing, anti-inflammatory, antimicrobial, antioxidant, laxative (caution)
7_31_aloe_vera.Traditional Uses: Traditional skin care, wound healing, digestive aid (caution), cooling, Ayurvedic pitta balance
7_31_aloe_vera.Modern Clinical Uses: Wound and burn healing, skin conditions (eczema, psoriasis), digestion support, skin care
7_31_aloe_vera.Medicinal Part Used: Gel (primary), latex (restricted use due to anthraquinones)
7_31_aloe_vera.Standard Dosage: Gel: topical application as needed; Internal: 1-2 tbsp juice daily (gel only, NOT latex)
7_31_aloe_vera.Internal Preparation Method: Fresh gel, juice, limited internal use (gel preferred; latex avoided internally)
7_31_aloe_vera.External Application Method: Fresh gel application, topical cream, oil infusion, wound dressing
7_31_aloe_vera.Culinary Uses: Edible gel in beverages, smoothies, desserts; latex NOT edible
7_31_aloe_vera.Extraction Process: Gel extraction (manual), juice extraction, water extraction of gel
7_31_aloe_vera.Toxicity Levels: Gel: Very low; Latex: MODERATE (anthraquinones cause purgative effects and potential toxicity)
7_31_aloe_vera.Contraindications: Latex INTERNALLY AVOID (strong purgative, potential toxicity); Pregnancy (internal use caution)
7_31_aloe_vera.Pregnancy & Lactation Safety: Gel safe topically in pregnancy; internal latex AVOID; gel juice minimal in lactation
7_31_aloe_vera.Drug-Herb Interactions: Latex may interact with medications (purgative effect); Gel minimal interactions
7_31_aloe_vera.Conservation Status: Not threatened, IUCN: Not evaluated (widely cultivated, secure)

7_32_nayontara.Local/Vernacular Names: Bengali: Nayontara, Sadabahar, Nosipushpi; English: Madagascar Periwinkle, Rosy Periwinkle; Hindi: Sadabahar
7_32_nayontara.Leaf Morphology: Oblong-elliptic, 2-5cm, glabrous, opposite arrangement, margin entire, leathery
7_32_nayontara.Native Habitat: Tropical deciduous forests, now cultivated widely
7_32_nayontara.Global Distribution: Madagascar native; pantropical cultivation, medicinal and ornamental
7_32_nayontara.Preferred Soil Type: Well-drained loamy soil, fertile, slightly acidic to neutral
7_32_nayontara.Traditional Uses: Traditional folk remedy for diabetes, blood sugar management, cancer research (alkaloids)
7_32_nayontara.Modern Clinical Uses: Cancer chemotherapy (pharmaceutical alkaloid isolation), diabetes support, antitumor research
7_32_nayontara.Standard Dosage: Limited traditional use; primarily pharmaceutical extraction; 1-3g herbal preparation maximum
7_32_nayontara.Internal Preparation Method: Decoction, infusion, powder (limited use; pharmaceutical extraction preferred)
7_32_nayontara.Extraction Process: Pharmaceutical alkaloid extraction, aqueous decoction (traditional limited use)
7_32_nayontara.Toxicity Levels: HIGH - Alkaloid content is potent; pharmaceutical use under medical supervision only
7_32_nayontara.Contraindications: Pregnancy ABSOLUTELY AVOID, lactation AVOID, internal use requires medical supervision
7_32_nayontara.Pregnancy & Lactation Safety: CONTRAINDICATED in pregnancy (cytotoxic alkaloids); AVOID in lactation
7_32_nayontara.Drug-Herb Interactions: SERIOUS: Potent alkaloids interact with multiple medications - pharmaceutical use only
7_32_nayontara.Conservation Status: Vulnerable (Madagascar endemic), IUCN: Vulnerable (habitat loss, collection pressure)

7_33_longevity_spinach_gainura.Local/Vernacular Names: Bengali: Gainura, Longevity Spinach; English: Longevity Spinach, Philippine Spinach, Waterleaf; Hindi: Rai-Kai, Gains
7_33_longevity_spinach_gainura.Leaf Morphology: Triangular to ovate, 2-5cm, glabrous, fleshy succulent, alternate arrangement
7_33_longevity_spinach_gainura.Native Habitat: Tropical cultivated areas, open disturbed areas
7_33_longevity_spinach_gainura.Global Distribution: Pantropical cultivation, Bangladesh, Southeast Asia, Africa
7_33_longevity_spinach_gainura.Preferred Soil Type: Well-drained sandy loam, adaptable, poor soil tolerant
7_33_longevity_spinach_gainura.Primary Active Compounds: Minerals (iron, calcium, potassium), vitamins (A, C), phytochemicals
7_33_longevity_spinach_gainura.Nutritional Profile: High in iron, calcium, beta-carotene, vitamin C, mineral-rich (longevity tonic status)
7_33_longevity_spinach_gainura.Therapeutic Properties: Nutritive, antioxidant, mineral-rich, anti-inflammatory, blood building
7_33_longevity_spinach_gainura.Traditional Uses: Traditional longevity tonic, blood building, nutritive support, energy enhancement
7_33_longevity_spinach_gainura.Modern Clinical Uses: Nutritional support, anemia management, mineral supplementation, traditional health
7_33_longevity_spinach_gainura.Standard Dosage: Fresh leaves 50-100g daily, cooked or raw, or 3-6g dried powder
7_33_longevity_spinach_gainura.Internal Preparation Method: Fresh leaves cooked as vegetable, salad, herbal tea, juice, powder
7_33_longevity_spinach_gainura.Culinary Uses: Edible vegetable in curries, soups, salads, stir-fries (tender leaves preferred)
7_33_longevity_spinach_gainura.Extraction Process: Water extraction, juice extraction, dried powder preparation
7_33_longevity_spinach_gainura.Pregnancy & Lactation Safety: Safe and beneficial in pregnancy and lactation; nutritive tonic
7_33_longevity_spinach_gainura.Conservation Status: Common, IUCN: Not evaluated (widely cultivated, secure)

7_34_betal.Local/Vernacular Names: Bengali: Betel, Paan Pata; English: Betel Pepper, Betel Vine; Hindi: Paan, Betel
7_34_betal.Leaf Morphology: Cordate (heart-shaped), 5-15cm long, acuminate, glabrous, alternate arrangement, aromatic
7_34_betal.Native Habitat: Tropical wet forests, cultivated on support structures
7_34_betal.Global Distribution: India, Bangladesh, Southeast Asia, South Asia
7_34_betal.Preferred Soil Type: Well-drained loamy soil, fertile, high humidity required
7_34_betal.Primary Active Compounds: Safrole, phenols, tannins, essential oils (betel oil), eugenol, anethole
7_34_betal.Therapeutic Properties: Antimicrobial, anthelmintic, carminative, digestive aid, oral health support, stimulant
7_34_betal.Traditional Uses: Traditional digestive stimulant, oral freshener, after-meal digestive aid, betel preparation
7_34_betal.Modern Clinical Uses: Oral health support, antimicrobial therapy, digestive stimulation, traditional use
7_34_betal.Standard Dosage: 1-3 leaves daily as paan (traditional preparation), fresh juice 5-10ml
7_34_betal.Internal Preparation Method: Fresh leaf chewing (traditional betel paan), juice, infusion, decoction
7_34_betal.Culinary Uses: Betel leaf chewing (with areca nut, lime, spices - traditional 'paan' practice)
7_34_betal.Extraction Process: Water extraction, 50% ethanol extraction, essential oil distillation
7_34_betal.Toxicity Levels: Low (safrole content minimal concern at traditional use levels); chronic chewing may increase oral cancer risk
7_34_betal.Contraindications: Pregnancy (mild stimulant effects caution), oral cancer risk (chronic betel chewing with other ingredients)
7_34_betal.Pregnancy & Lactation Safety: Minimal concern at normal use; caution with excessive chewing in pregnancy
7_34_betal.Conservation Status: Common, IUCN: Not evaluated (widely cultivated, culturally significant)
